qas.question: What were greenware ceramics made from?
What color tint is Longquan greenware characterized by?
What period did Longquan ceramics decline?
What kilns were Longquan kilns replaced by in popularity and production?
What decorations are Yuan Longquan celadons derived from?
What were blueware ceramics made from?
What were redware ceramics made from?
What period did Longquan ceramics rise?
What kilns were Longquan kilns not replaced by in popularity and production?
What decorations are Yuan Longquan non-celadons derived from?

context: Greenware ceramics made from <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>celadon<b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> had been made in the area since the 3rd-century Jin dynasty, but it returned to prominence—particularly in Longquan—during the Southern Song and Yuan. Longquan greenware is characterized by a thick unctuous glaze of a particular <a1_0>bluish-green<a1_0/> tint over an otherwise undecorated light-grey porcellaneous body that is delicately potted. Yuan Longquan celadons feature a thinner, greener glaze on increasingly large vessels with decoration and shapes derived from <a4_0>Middle Eastern<a4_0/> ceramic and metalwares. These were produced in large quantities for the Chinese export trade to Southeast Asia, the <b9_0>Middle East<b9_0/>, and (during the Ming) Europe. By <a2_0><b7_0>the Ming<b7_0/><a2_0/>, however, production was notably deficient in quality. It is in this period that the Longquan kilns declined, to be eventually replaced in popularity and ceramic production by the kilns of <a3_0><b8_0>Jingdezhen in Jiangxi<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
